name: Jan Chapman
description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Jan Chapman
key_work.brief_description: Jan Chapman is an Australian film producer, who has produced some of our most beloved and critically acclaimed films, including The Last Days of Chez Nous (1992), The Piano (1993), Love Serenade (1996), Holy Smoke! (1999) and Lantana (2001).

constellations_primary.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_primary.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

start.title: Spotlights: Jan Chapman
start.brief_description: Jan Chapman is an Australian film producer, who has produced some of our most beloved and critically acclaimed films, including The Last Days of Chez Nous (1992), The Piano (1993), Love Serenade (1996), Holy Smoke! (1999) and Lantana (2001).

constellations_primary.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_primary.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

end.title: The Last Days of Chez Nous
end.brief_description: The story of sisters Vicki and Beth, when Vicki begins an affair with Beth’s intriguing French husband.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Around the early 1970s, Chapman ran the Filmmaker’s Cinema above a socialist bookstore in Sydney, which screened works by directors who would form the Australian New Wave, including Gillian Armstrong, who made The Last Days of Chez Nous, which Chapman produced.

start.title: The Last Days of Chez Nous
start.brief_description: The story of sisters Vicki and Beth, when Vicki begins an affair with Beth’s intriguing French husband.

end.title: The Piano
end.headline_credit: Aotearoa / New Zealand, Australia and France, 1993
end.brief_description: The piano used in Jane Campion’s award-winning classic dates from 1825–30 and was shipped to the New Zealand from London. Two replicas were made – a lightweight version that could be carried through the bush and one with a steel frame for underwater scenes.

constellations_primary.name: When music speaks
constellations_primary.description: Some characters or moments are expressed more intensely through a musical motif than dialogue or action.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Two years after being nominated for the AFI Award for Best Picture with Chez Nous, Chapman received the Academy Award nomination for Best Picture at the 1994 Oscars, for Jane Campion’s classic The Piano.

start.brief_description: The piano used in Jane Campion’s award-winning classic dates from 1825–30 and was shipped to the New Zealand from London. Two replicas were made – a lightweight version that could be carried through the bush and one with a steel frame for underwater scenes.

end.title: Top of the Lake
end.creator_credit: Escapade Pictures, Screen Australia and See-Saw Films
end.brief_description: A woman haunted by her past, Detective Robin Griffin, investigates complex and unsettling cases.

constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: After decades forging an acclaimed career, director Jane Campion returned to New Zealand (where The Piano is set) to make another acclaimed work, the TV series Top of the Lake, a story about a missing young girl and the community’s reaction to her disappearance.

start.title: The Last Days of Chez Nous
start.brief_description: The story of sisters Vicki and Beth, when Vicki begins an affair with Beth’s intriguing French husband.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

end.title: Monkey Grip
end.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Patricia Lovell and Pavilion Films
end.brief_description: Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless artists who refuse to live by the conventional rules.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: The Last Days of Chez Nous was written by celebrated Australian author Helen Garner. Ten years earlier, Garner’s novel Monkey Grip (1977) was adapted for the screen by director Ken Cameron. It follows a group of young artists through Melbourne share houses in the 1970s.

start.title: Monkey Grip
start.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Patricia Lovell and Pavilion Films
start.brief_description: Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless artists who refuse to live by the conventional rules.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

end.title: Dogs in Space
end.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Like Monkey Grip, Dogs in Space is a film that follows the exploits of artists and drug users through share houses and the post-punk music scene in Melbourne, during the same period of the late 1970s. It starred INXS front man Michael Hutchence.

start.title: Dogs in Space
start.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

end.title: Backroads
end.brief_description: Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Jan Chapman ran the Filmmaker’s Cinema with her first husband, Phillip Noyce. A filmmaker himself, Noyce’s debut film was Backroads, which starred Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor Gary Foley, who also appeared in Dogs in Space.

start.title: Monkey Grip
start.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Patricia Lovell and Pavilion Films
start.brief_description: Explores the joys and traumas of a group of people living in Melbourne’s inner-city. Revolving around the life of a single mother sharing a communal house, the film portrays the lives of talented and reckless artists who refuse to live by the conventional rules.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: The soundtrack to Monkey Grip was produced by the rock band Divinyls, with lead singer Chrissy Amphlett appearing in a small role in the movie. Eight years after recording the film’s soundtrack, the band released their most popular single ‘I Touch Myself’.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

end.title: Bad Boys
end.creator_credit: Michael Bay, Bobbie Read, Don Simpson, Jerry Bruckheimer, Columbia Pictures, Don Simpson/Jerry Bruckheimer Films, Sony Pictures, John Vallone, Doug Richardson, Jim Mulholland, Michael Barrie and George Gallo
end.brief_description: Marcus Burnett is a hen-pecked family man. Mike Lowry is a foot-loose and fancy free ladies’ man. Both are Miami policemen, and both have 72 hours to reclaim a consignment of drugs stolen from under their station’s nose. To complicate matters, in order to get the assistance of the sole witness to a murder, they have to pretend to be each other.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Curiously, the music video for ‘I Touch Myself’ was directed by none other than explosion aficionado Michael Bay. Like many directors, Bay started his career directing music videos. When producers Jerry Bruckheimer and Don Simpson noticed his work, they had him direct his first feature: Bad Boys.
